Text: If I wished to control other devices with my Samsung tablet or phone, I would be very pleased to give Samsung the courtesy of considering this app. But I don't have this need. It's easy for the Samsungs of the world to convince themselves that customers were put on this earth to generate revenue and provide them with an endless torrent of consumer behaviour data. But we pay your salaries and keep the lights on, so you can come up with products that we CHOOSE to buy. Or not buy. Finally, a plea to Tony of Smart Things support: It is pleasing to see Samsung responding to customer complaints about this and other aspects of this app. But I urge you to not thank me for this feedback and assure me that you have passed it on. I don't mean to shoot the messenger but you should know that these insipid and insincere responses just increase the suspicion and mistrust of the people who pay your collective wages. If you want to try a novel new approach, perhaps you could respond instead with an unambiguous undertaking by Samsung to resolve this by a specific date, or provide a plausible explanation of what is preventing Samsung from doing so.

Stars: Rated 1 stars out of five stars
Text: What a POS! What the hell happened with Samsung this last year - I've had more Samsung issues this last year than all the other years combined. What a completely stupid idea to take the Samsung Connect app and rename it to "SmartThings" when there is already an app called SmartThings (now labeled SmartThings Classic.) And why were users not notified first and allowed to decide for themselves whether or not they want the app update. If I had just bought a SmartThings system and came home to find 2 different apps in the Play store called SmartThings, I would be confused and probably look at the version number of each app - but that would be a mistake because old SmartThings has a higher version number than new SmartThings. At this point I would have just sent it back to Amazon. I never liked or used Smart Connect much - just to set up my wifi hub because that was the only method provided. The original SmartThings app isn't perfect, but it's way superior to the half-baked new app based on Smart Connect - which was used mostly for Bluetooth devices, but is now being shoehorned into a home automation platform. I hope they don't plan on getting rid of the original app and forcing existing SmartThings customers to use the new app exclusively or they're will be a lot of protests and probably a lot of people dumping ST altogether. You see the hub is cheap compared to the many hundreds and hundreds of dollars for sensors, lights, locks, cameras, thermostats, etc. which will all work just fine with another vendors hub. Samsung doesn't own the Zigbee & Z-Wave protocols, nor is there any special proprietary tech in their hubs, so you can just swap out the ST hub for one from a different manufacturer and reattach all of your "things" and only be out the cost of the ST hub. Are you listening Samsung? As an IT Engineer myself I can tell you that the golden rule of IT support is to not piss off the users of your platform/network/system. Taking away something they have and are happy with and forcing a migration to something new and frankly inferior, violates the DNPOTU rule. ST Help Desk: please spare me your scripted response about how sorry you are for my inconvenience, inviting me to contact you for support. I've had multiple encounters with your offshore support people who can barely speak English and are oftentimes outright rude... I remember trying to have a conversation with a particular woman who was giving me what I knew to be incorrect information - when I asked to speak to a manager, she told me that she felt like she resolved my issue and that I "did not deserve to speak to a manager" then she hung up on me.
